Award.AwardTitle: Expert-Novice Framework to Support Student and Instructor Feedback on Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Design skills and knowledge are critical to all fields of engineering as engineers design innovative solutions to meet the needs of today and tomorrow. Developing students? design understanding and abilities is thus a critical enterprise for the field of engineering education. However, a key ingredient in the design learning process is the feedback that students receive on both their design products and design processes. This engineering education research project builds on the investigators? prior experiences with characterizing and improving the feedback that instructors (as well as students themselves) provide on engineering students? mathematical modeling work. In this project, the investigators examine the differences that exist in the feedback provided by expert design educators compared to newer design educators compared to students (in peer review) to (1) characterize the form and substance of the feedback that expert design educators provide to promote learning and (2) develop materials to help students as well as less-experienced instructors learn how to provide better feedback. These materials will first be used to help local (i.e. Purdue) students and instructors to provide better feedback, and after assessing the effectiveness of the materials, the investigators will share the materials widely through publications and workshops to provide opportunities for other educators to improve their design feedback skills.

The findings of this research will have impact across design education and enhance the ability of faculty to create experiences that meet the attributes being called for by engineering accreditation boards, the National Academy of Engineering, and industry leaders in today's global economy. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Design is a central and defining aspect of engineering practice. Many different educational agents play a role in providing feedback on students’ design work including professors, graduate teaching assistants, undergraduate teaching assistants, external project partners (from industry or a community organization), and other students. The goal of this work was to deepen our understanding of the differences between feedback provided by those along a continuum from novices (students) to experts (engineer educators and practicing engineers). Knowledge of these differences could then be used to educate novices on giving more expert-like feedback. 

Studies were conducted in which various agents gave feedback on a single sample of student design work representing a full design process from understanding the design problem to full detailing of the final design idea. Overall, experts provided a greater number of feedback comments that were longer and included more details and examples. The type and content of the feedback was also different. With regards to the type of feedback, experts encouraged students to be similar to expert designers, who explore and critically evaluate multiple ideas before choosing a solution. They asked thought-provoking questions and provided brainstorming prompts in an effort to help students explore different design alternatives before selecting a design idea to fully detail. Novices focused their feedback on trying to fix the design idea rather than prompt more exploration of alternatives - they provided feedback on what needed to be changed and specific instructions on how to improve the design work. Experts treated feedback as more of a dialog than students, engaging in expressions of confusion over design decision; novices were less likely to indicate that they did not understand aspects of the design work.  

In terms of feedback content, novices focused on communication aspects of the design work.  Experts focused less on communication and more on the design concepts themselves.  Both novices and experts gave equal attention in their feedback to the design processes employed to develop the design. Both novices and experts gave little feedback on the connection between the design and its intended users and others potentially impacted by the design (e.g., those who might have to maintain the final product).

The results of the studies were used to frame professional development workshops related to design feedback. The intention of the workshops was to furnish participants with experiences and insights to build capacity for providing more expert-like feedback. Professional development was created and delivered to students, teaching assistants, engineering educators and practicing engineers. From these professional workshop experiences, a number of recommendations for giving such workshops evolved. First, give participants an opportunity to provide feedback on sample design work. Second, describe the different feedback types and content for design.  Third, guide participants to evaluate their feedback in terms of feedback type and content, highlighting with examples novice and expert differences.  Finally, provide conversation space for participants to learn how others provide feedback on similar work, as well as more generally approach feedback on design.
